item.title: Dragon Quest VII Reimagined Review - One Fragment After Another
item.content:encoded:
The Dragon Quest series is on a bit of a roll lately, clearly laying the ground for the eventual release of Dragon Quest XII - whenever that decides to come out of hiding again. But before all that, Square Enix has been hard at work offering up remakes to several of the older games in the series.

First, we had Dragon Quest III HD-2D, followed by Dragon Quest I and II released last year. Now things are skipping ahead a bit, with Dragon Quest VII Reimagined heading the lineup.

Unlike its contemporaries, Dragon Quest VII Reimagined is exactly that. It’s shed the more 2D look of the original PlayStation version and opted for a 3D diorama art direction. What this means is everything exists in a 3D environment - including the player characters.

This isn’t even the first time Dragon Quest VII was redone in 3D. A 3DS remake had its own visual style, but Reimagined goes beyond that. With such a departure from both that and the original, I suppose the question at large is: does it work? And does it vibe with the other recent remakes?

At first glance, it’s easy to be wary - after all, Square Enix spent a lot of time getting people used to the HD 2D style. That doesn’t mean their 3D efforts have gone astray, however.

Digging into Dragon Quest VII Reimagined is like visiting an old friend I never got the chance to actually meet. That is to say, as someone who didn’t play the original, all of this was going to be delightfully fresh and without the burden of nostalgia goggles.

That said, it’s clear right away that Dragon Quest VII Reimagined is a love letter to the style of RPGs we got out of the PlayStation era.

Dragon Quest VII Reimagined follows the series’ traditional silent protagonist as he makes his way as a young boy in the fishing town of Pilchard Bay, located on the world’s one and only island. After a short introduction to his family and his father’s discovery of a mysterious looking stone fragment, he meets up with his childhood friend Kiefer, who decides to do a little exploring.

The pair comes across a mysterious shrine and is convinced there’s something else out there. The fragments they’ve obtained seem to feature some sort of map, and soon enough, they’re able to gather enough that leads them to a new island in an unfamiliar world.

As it turns out, things aren’t what they seem, and it’s clear there’s a higher power at play here. These fragments of the past, as it is soon discovered, paint the picture of lands that were obscured for many years. The party at hand helps the people in need, vanquishes the foe behind it all, and then returns to the present, where it turns out that same island has just appeared in their own time.

This is just one of many cases, and the protagonist, along with Kiefer and their friend Maribel, will have to continue to collect fragments to uncover even more lost islands. Of course, they eventually discover even bigger forces at play as the party bulks up, but the meat of the story takes place in each of these island vignettes.

That is to say, while yes, there is an overarching plot, I found the individual quests held most of the emotional weight and narrative meat of the story. Tales of a whole village turned to stone, and tales of an island doomed to the flood, are just some examples out of many that fly in the face of a larger, looming darkness.

Even though the time spent on each island isn’t particularly long, the characters in each of these stories have plenty of heart. Dragon Quest VII Reimagined’s core party is fairly stock standard, but that isn’t a bad thing when they become a vehicle to witness these other stories.

The biggest draw for me with the cast was how different they all were from each other. There’s the young protagonist, but Kiefer is an adventurous prince, Maribel is the fierce childhood friend, Ruff is a feral young boy with a wolf companion, and later on, characters like Aishe and Mervyn round out those with different worldly experiences.

This becomes especially apparent when taking them into battle. Dragon Quest VII Reimagined operates on a traditional turn-based system. That is to say that each party member and enemy takes turns making their move.

It’s all very much the classic turn-based battles with some additional twists. Firstly, battles can be initiated by approaching visible enemies on the field. Then, once in battle, tactics can be set to ease the flow of each turn. Characters can also fight using the CPU with the auto battle option.

On top of this, Dragon Quest VII Reimagined offers a full job system - that is characters have the ability to equip not just one, but two vocations with the Moonlighting system. What this does is offer up different abilities and stats that sort of combine with each other, and jobs can be swapped out on the regular to mix up gameplay.

For example, I found equipping Maribel with both Sage and Mage vocations doubled up her magic for powerful results. The same with focusing the protagonist as both a Fisherman and a Martial Artist. Truly, the combinations are endless, and it’s worth tinkering with different builds for each character.

Each job also allows for a specific Let Loose mechanic when characters become worked up. These special attacks can hit pretty hard and can offer a boost to the party when needed, which is why the ability to swap jobs whenever possible is so special.

Outside of battle, Dragon Quest VII Reimagined involves a lot of collecting. There’s a lot of going around and exploring for the fragments needed for the main scenario, but also side items like medals and gear, and along the way, there are environmental puzzles and the Lucky Panel minigame that involves a visual matching game and a battle arena.

While there’s not a lot of exterior content, there’s also some additional dungeons that provide more of a challenge in the late game, and being able to go back through after the main story is finished is certainly a plus. It’s helpful too for snagging any missed fragments - after a point, I did feel like I was more set on getting to the end with the copious amount of backtracking and pacing problems throughout the same areas involved.

But despite these hangups, Dragon Quest VII Reimagined is delightful in its visual presentation. With the 3D dioramas and character models in play, there’s a very specific charm that hasn’t quite been done in the series yet. Combined with the classic score done up for the modern age, the presentation leaves little to desire.

All said, Dragon Quest VII Reimagined is a solid outing in every sense of the word. If you’ve never played the original, like me, there are hours to dig into. If you’re a returning player, the additions to the job system might be the big thing that catches your eye.

Either way, and despite some tedium, Square Enix has done a solid job bringing Dragon Quest VII into the modern age. I’ll be very curious to see where the series goes next.

TechRaptor reviewed Dragon Quest VII Reimagined on PlayStation 5 with a code provided by the publisher. All screenshots were taken over the course of 52 hours of gameplay.
